text: It's a balmy night in August, 1940. We open on the exteri of a swank Atlantic City nightclub, its dazzling facade illuminating a passing parade of hipsters, which stops li a freeze dance every time the club door opens and allows few bars of the music within to escape. It's the dream of every hipster that a party of fifteen will come out, keep the door open long enough perhaps to hear Ziggy Elman's entire trumpet solo on "Body and Soul'.

This time, however, only a couple emerges, accompanied at best by a few diminished eighth notes. The man, elegantly dressed and refined in manner, is immediately recognizabl as Kid Twist, the bogus telegra h operator in "The Sting. On his arm is a statuesque blonde in clinging crepe. ey proceed to a cab and slide in the back.

As Twist leans forward to give instructions to the cabbie he fails to notice that the woman slides right out the ot side. He turns to find that her place has been taken by a huge hulk of a man who says nothing and stares straight ahead. Twist has seen that look before and moves to get o the way he cam in, only to find that there is now a thug the other side of him too. This one closes the door besid him and assumes the same pose as his friend. Twist realiz that he's in trouble. The cabbie pulls out with no word from the thugs. It doesn't matter. He knows better than they do where they're going. cut To

The camera moves in slowly on a man sitting alone in the dark, his head partially illuminated by the lights from t amusement park across the street. The only sound in the room comes from an unseen fan. The camera stops when we'r close enough to realize that the man is Doyle Lonnegan th gangster/mark of "The Sting." His eyes are set and far of
his face lost in thought. A knock is heard at the door, and Lonnegan jumps a bit as if someone had just snuck up on him. We hear a voice outside. It's Floyd, Lonnegan's right-hand man.
Doyle. Homer's downstairs. They made a clean snatch on Twist. You want us to dump him?
No, bring him here. I wanta see him first.
Okay. (noticing that there's no light coming under the door) You all right in there?
I'm all right.
as Floyd walks on down the hall.

Lonnegan slips back into his reverie. The camera starts t move in on him again. We burn into his eyes, which never blink despite the play of the neon across them. We hear: A sound montage of the replay of the last few minutes of "The Sting." 1. he voice of Lonnegan placing his half million dollar bet with great bravado, the call of a race in the b.g. 2. Kid Twist telling Lonnegan that he's bet incorrectly and will lose all his money. 3. Lonnegan trying frantically almost hysterically, to ge his money back from the cashier.
4. A fusilade of gun shots. 5. The voice of Detective Snyder urging Lonnegan out of t betting parlor. Again a knock is heard at the door.-

Come in. The door opens to reveal Twist and his two captors sil- houetted in the doorway. Lonnegan reaches out and turns on a light, and for the first time we are able to see the room. It looks like an expensive suite in any luxury hote except that the walls are covered with photographs, 8 x 1 blowups of every single man involved in the con of Lonneg some four years before. Prominently displayed above the others, like the leaders of some Eastern European politbu are shots of Gondroff and Hooker. Lonnegan allows Twist to take in the room before he speak Twist tries heard not to notice the photographs.
What do you think of my pictures Twist?
My name's not Twist, and I don't know much about pictures.
You find yours yet?
I don't know why a picture of me would be up there.
(without taking his eyes off Twist On the wall to your left. Fourth one from the right. Between Curly Jackson and J.J. Singleton. Twist doesn't bother to look at the photograph. He knows it's there.
I coulda picked somebody else. I know where most of them are now. You just happened to be the closest.
I got no idea what you're talkin' about. I don't know any of these people....

Four years ago, forty-seven months and six days to be exact, you helped them take me for half a million dol- lars. I should think you'd remember at. Look, you got me mixed up with somebody eise. I....

(not even listening to Twist You played the telegraph operator, the guy who held up the race results. I'll never forget when you came in and told me I'd screwed ug the bet. Acting like it was the end of the world when inside you had to be jumping up and down. Gondorff musta been proud of you, Twist. I wish you could remember it. I had hoped it would have meant more to you to take a man like me. (offerin his hand T can only congratulate you on a job beautifully done. Lonnegan has attempted to deliver all this with a "no har feelings" attitude, but Twist is not fooled. He knows the will be no reprieve for him. He decides to go out like a champ .
Believe me, Lonnegan, it was the greatest day of my life. cut To

Lonnegan and Floyd are sitting in a car looking out over the river to a warehouse on the other side. All the light are out in the warehouse, except for one on the second st at the top of a fifty-foot-long loading chute which runs from the second floor out over the water. It is normally used to convey cargo from the warehouse to freight barges
below. lLonnegan and Floyd have their eyes glued to it, expecting something to happen there soon. Floyd, in par- ticular, seems to be anxious.

You shouldn't be here, Doyle. LONNEGAN us Get the word out that Macalinski put Kid Twist with the fishes. A body, feet encased in concrete, goes speeding down the loading chute and disappears below the surface of the bla water.
That's one. With a gesture to Floyd, Lonnegan sits back grimly, and the car moves off. Main title and opening credits.

We pick up Johnny Hooker washing himself in a makeshift shower that he's rigged up on the fire escape of his one~ room apartment. He uses old bed sheets for a curtain and his shower head consists of.a comb taped over the end of a garden hose which runs in through the window to a fauce on the small sink which occupies one corner of his totall undistinguished room. Hooker is obviously in an expansive mood, as he sings alo to the radio which he's hung on the landing above him. It's playing Helen Ward's version of "Goody Goody" with t Benny Goodman orchestra. His rinse water, meanwhile, drip through the grating of the fire escape to the pavement si floors below, watering several window boxes on the way. Hooker finishes up, and climbs back through his window.
As he's toweling off, the Eirie Kid enters the room.
Hey, where's your suit?
I decided not to wear it. It'll just get dirty on the streetcar. HOOKER . What are you talking about? I rented a limousine.
A limousine to go to the fights.
we! re management now, Eirie. When you re the owner of an up and comin’ ight-heavy you don't show up on no streetcar.

But our guy ain't even fightin' to- night. HOOKER — So what. You. want everybody to think we're small-time? Christ, the kid could be fightin' for the title inside a year, and you wanta show up on a goddamn trolley. bus woulda been better than that.
We can't afford no bus, let a limo. Eirie notices a new pair of shoes on a chair.
Those your boats?
(proud as heli) How you like 'em, huh? Alligator Brazillian. Eirie looks them over like they're stale bread.

Hooker, I think we oughta skip the fight and see if we can’t get our- selves some pocket money. You know that dame I been tellin' ya about down at the Gardens? Weli I been studyin' her and I know we can take her for a bundle.
I don't like it, Eirie. I promised myself I was gonna go legit.
You're just nervous, that's all. We're both a little rusty. We'll get over it once we get into the pitch. I know we still got our touch.
It's bad enough goin' back on the grift, but connin' women. That's low, Eirie. We used to have a rule No poor people and no women.

That was pregnant women, and this one ain't carryin' nothin' but dough. I tell ya, this dame is a thoroughbred, been in there two or three nights in a row, never talkin' to nobody but this oid broad that hangs around with her. She dresses like a champion, but I can tell she don't know her way around.
: He I still don't like it.
You like livin' in this pigpen better? You're already Bao o  months behind on the rent. e only rea~ son they ain't thrown you out is they couldn't get anybody else to live here.
Well you're the bookkeeper of the operation. Why don't you pay the damn rent?
I can't. You're overdrawn four grand at the bank. Eirie is interrupted by a knock at the door.
Hooker goes to answer it, half-dressed in a pair of socks
with knee on them. 10 suspenders and green shorts with the letters YMCA It's a Deliveryman with a tuxedo in his hand.
Tuxedo for Mr. Hooker.
That's me. (handing over a dollar bill) Here's a little somethin' for your trouble, buddy.
How about a little somethin' for the tux?
(easing the guy out the door} Bill me. Hooker turns back to Eirie and begins to putting on his t
How can I be overdrawn? The last time I looked in there, I had _ eighty gees.

That was two-and-a-half years ago, before you started buyin! prize fi inters, race horses, zinc mines every other goddamn thing. That stuff's gonna * Pay off, Eirie. It just takes time, at's all. In the world of investment, you gotta spend money to make money.
Hooker, I'm tellin' ya, if you don't do somethin' pretty fast, you're gonna start gettin' visits from the coppers Hooker knows that Eirie's right. People are gonna make so noise over four grand.
(resigned) All right eit call the girls and tell ‘em we'll be a little late.
The girls?
You're gonna like these two, Eirie. They're hat checkers at the Rondella.
Christ, what am I gonna say to these babes? I don't know nothin' about ats. As Hooker dials his call, we: cur TO

location: THE MARINE ROOM OF THE STEEL PIER

text: One of the great ballrooms of the era, in a class with th Roseland in New York and the Aragon and Trianon in Chicag Featuring an ocean of hardwood dance floor, divided here and there into inlets and bays by the arrangements of the tables, the Marine was a must play date for all the big swing bands of the forties. Not as elegant certainly as the supper clubs, but more exciting. The band's female vocalist is just getting into "You Turn The Tables On Me" as Hooker and Eirie enter the ballroom.
She's at table sixteen, on the left toward the front.

Hooker's eyes search the floor and finally come to rest o table sixteen. He's not quite ready for what he finds there. He had expected the Woman to be rich, but he hadn' expected her to be beautiful. Regal in bearing, she has the untouchable beauty of a Hedy Lamarr. The kind that turns passing strangers into employees. Hooker's first instinct is to turn around and go home. He has barely noticed the Older Woman to_her left, who is plainly dress and exudes a professional protectiveness toward her com- panion.
What'd I tell ya, huh? If she ain't loaded with jack, I don't know my own name. :
a
I don't feel right about this, Eirie. - I mean, she's with her mother and Eirie was taining a paper cut everything.
Look, this is no slight on her. She happens to be keepin’ company with some cash. It's not like you hate the dame. Someday when you're a millionaire, you can buy her a bracelet or somethin’.

Hell, we don't even have any props with us. What are we gonna take her on? prepared for this. He takes out an envelope con- stack of fake money: and another one containing up the size of dollar bills.
I got the boodle and the stiff right here. All we gotta do is back it with some real green and we got everything we need. How muc! cash you got?
Fifteen bucks.
I got twenty. We'll put mine on top and yours on the bottom. It ain't great, but it's good enough. Eirie puts the twenty on the top of the false bankroll, and the ten on the bottom. This is a

Your problem is you're lettin' her looks go to your head. Since when have you ever gotten to first base with a dame like that? These society types think they're too good for . regular people. She wouldn't be seen outside a barnyard with either one of us. very telling point with Hooker. His heart be- gins to harden agains e Woman.

You're right, Eirie. That kinda babe gives me the pip. Shot through with new motivation, Hooker looks at the Woman like she's a barbell to be cleaned and jerked. He's a complete professional now. He takes off his watch and hands it to Eirie, then snatches a flower out of a vase and puts it in his lapel. We follow him as he makes his way over to table sixteen.
Hooker immediately affects the demeanor of an entrepeneur
Excuse me, ladies. You haven't by chance seen a gold watch around here, have you? (through a thick French accent) No, I do not think so, Mr....
Stewart. Charles Stewart. I'm the ’ manager here.
Pleased to meet you, Mr. Stewart. I am Veronique LeFleur, and....
(interrupting) The Countess Veronique Fabian LeFleur.
(slightly embarrassed) Giselle, they do not care about these things in America. (to Hooker) This is my maid servant, Giselle Duvillard. We are sorry that you lost your watch.
Oh, it wasn't mine, Miss LeFleur.
Countess LeFleur.
Giselle!
A Mr. Jerome Hawthorne lost it in here tonight, and is quite anxious to get it back. It's an Elgin Special with a monogrammed J.H. on e back. He's offering a thousand dollar reward for its return.

(honestl. relieved Oh, then it's not an expensive one. Hooker struggles to maintain his nonchalance in the face such a remar It's a hard one for a poor boy to swallow. He looks for some indication that she may be kidding. He doesn't get one.
Well, it was just that it was very personal to Mr. Hawthorne. It was given to him by his father just be- ore he was killed in the Battle of Belaue Wood.
(truly moved) Oh, how sad, If we find it, we will bring it to ou, how do you ' say...on the doub
Both women permit themselves a little laugh at their mast of this English idiom.
(taking his leave Thank you, Miss LeFleur.
(sullenly) Countess LeFleur.
We follow him as he returns to Eirie, out of sight of the two women.
You were right, Eirie. Money's nothin' to her. She's a countess.
HOOKER (Cont'd) French. Not a bad egg for a coun- tess. Maybe in France they're not so snot-nosed. It's obvious that Veronique's charm has rekindled some second thoughts in Hooker.
Aw c'mon. Underneath they're all alike. You're not softening up on me, are ya Hooker?
This time we follow Eirie as he makes his way to the tabl He boldly props himself down right next to Veronique in t booth, talking to her in a conspiritorial fashion, out of the side of his mouth.

Look lady, I know you don't know me, but I need a little help. The manager here's got it in for me, and I'd appreciate it if you could pretend like we was friends and everything. Like we been sittin’ here for a long time, havin' a - nice evening....
as Hooker suddenly appears at the table. Eirie pretends t be carrying on a conversation with the woman, who doesn't know what to make of him.
. {to Eirie) Fisher, I thought I told you to stay outta here.

It's a free country, Stewart. A man can dance if he wants to. (to the Countess) . Me and my date was just about to cut up the rug a little, wasn't we honey? The Countess doesn't know what to say. She has no idea what Eirie is talking about.
Stand up and empty out your pockets.
Eirie hesitates a second, then stands up and reluctantly empties out his pockets. He shows nothing but a wallet and a pair of keys.
See, I'm clean.
Good, then you won't have anything to weigh you down on the way out. Or do I have to call the police?
(deciding it's _ time to leave) All right, all right. I didn't want to hang out in this dive anyway. Eirie beats a speedy retreat.
Who was that man?
Oh, he's a cheap crook. A pickpocket, a fence, you name it.

Both women are visibly frightened to have been in the pre sence of such a man. Veronique glances down at where Eiri was sitting and something catches her eye -- there's a go watch on the seat. She picks it up quickly and hands it t Hooker.
Mr. Stewart, there's a watch here. I think it's your friend's.
(inspecting the watch) . It's Hawthorne's all right. Fisher probably stole it from him and took it out of his pocket when I asked to search him. The women are really scared now.
Aren't you going to call the police?
Wouldn't do any good unless we had found the watch on him. Whatever, you found the watch. You have a reward coming.
Oh, but I could not take it. I have done nothing to deserve it.
I insist. Mr. Hawthorne will be very unhappy with me if I don't follow his instructions. You found the watch. The money is yours. Please, he will be most insulted if you turn it down.
_ (resigned) . All right, I do not wish to offend the man. . _ (to Giselle) When in America, I suppose we must do as the Americans.
hands her the envelope with the boodle in it. She puts it in her purse without even bothering to check it.

Excuse me, but if I may be so bold, I wouldn't carry that money in your purse. Not in a neighborhood like this. You walk down the street with a purse in plain view, you're gonna lose it. ere are twenty other thieves outside just like Fisher, only worse. The two women are immediately concerned.
What should we do? HOOKER . Here, let me show you something. If I were you, I'd put all my money in the envelope.
complies, immediately, pulling out a bankroll that knocks

Hooker's eyes out. She puts it into the envelope and then passes it to Giselle, who dips into her purse and adds he money to it. She turns her body as she does so, so that Hooker cannot see how much money she has. Hooker is amuse by her modesty. Giselle then licks the envelope and seals it.
May I have the envelope a second? Giselle hesitates, but Veronique makes her hand it over.

All right, you take the envelope and stick it up under your arm, inside your coat, like this. Hooker demonstrates by slipping the envelope inside his tuxedo coat and up into his armpit. By shooting from the side, we see that there is already another envelope there the one with the cut paper.

That way you can feel it all the time, and no pickpickets will be looking for it there. He reaches back inside his coat and pulls out the envelop but of course it's not the one he put in. It's the one wi the cut paper. He hands it to Veronique, who thanks him a hands it to Giselle, who tucks it up inside her coat, gla ing both ways to make sure no one saw her do it. HOOKER . I am sorry for all the commotion here tonight. I hope you enjoyed your evening, Countess. Giselle allows herself a little smile that Hooker is fina using the proper term of address. The Countess nods that evening has been satisfactory, and Hooker takes his leave
We follow him as he walks right on out of the ballroom an joins Eirie on the street.
Hooker is not nearly as elated as we might expect.
Everything go okay? : 39 ¥ CONTINUED  22 23 24
Yeah, it was easy. I don't even think we needed the build up. I coulda asked 'em for the money out- right and they'da given it to me. Not that I'm proud of it.

(hefting the envelope) Yeah, well let me see what we got here. Feels like enough to open our own steel mill. Eirie rips open the envelope and pulls out the most beaut ful stack of construction paper we've ever seen. Not a dollar bill in sight. Both Hooker and Eirie stare at it i shock for a secon Then it begins to dawn on then.
Hooker, we been had. Barely are the words out of Eirie’s mouth than Hooker rac back into the cl
Hooker zeroes in on table sixteen. It's empty. He races back outside.

Hooker frantically looks up and down the street for some sign of the two women. HOOKER ; I find that broad, I'm gonna wring her neck. Forget it. She’ 5 TRrobably halfway home with our thirty bucks by now. Wouldn't that rot your socks. Eirie is somewhat amused by the whole thing. Hooker is fit to be tied. He literally begins jumping up and down.

We gotta do somethin'. We'll call the police, that's what we'll do. Christ, what kinda town are they runnin' where people can 90, around pullin' this sorta thing. This burg is crawlin' with grifters and the cops are pickin’ nose.  25 26 27
Eirie can't believe this outpouring of righteousness from Hooker. Hooker continues his tirade as they get into thei limousine.

Usin' construction paper yet. Think how the people who made that paper would feel if they knew what she was using it for. They thought. the’ were makin’ somethin' nice for little kids. This is the kinda thing that gives construction paper a bad name.
As the limousine pulls out, we move to reveal that Lonneg man, Floyd, has been watching the departure from a car ac the street. We can't see who's in the back seat, but we c guess. cut To

The limousine pulls up in front of the building and Hooke and Eirie get out. hey are just about to go up the front steps when two thugs jump out of the shadows, scaring the hell out of all of us, not to mention Hooker and Eirie. Hooker tries to run for it, but he's caught and slammed u against a wall.
You Johnny Hooker?
Maybe.
We're from Atlas Tuxedo. You told our guy to bill you. We checked your credit -- you ain't got none. Our boss don't like to be stiffed. That tux'll be ten bucks.
I ain't got it.
Then you either give up the tux or your good looks. Hooker pulls out his pockets with his best "have mercy" smile. He looks from some sign that it's winning the thugs over. Fat chance.

INT. HOOKER'S APARTMENT BUILDING’~ STAIRWAY - NIGHT 28 walking up the stairs of Hooker's apartment building. Hooker, having lost the tuxedo, is now clad only in his YMCA m shorts, his knee socks (suspenders) and, of course his alligator shoes. It hasn't been his night.

Ya know with things a little tough and all, maybe we oughta go see Gondorff. s letter said he's got a big house down there in Florida with a yard and everything. We could lie around in the sun a little, maybe borrow a few bucks.
I'm not goin' down there with my hat in my hand. He thinks I don't know how to take care of myself.
He's not gonna be like that. He's in the chips. He'd be glad to help ya out.
(tired as hell) . I don't know. We'll talk about it in the morning.
Eirie starts off toward his room as Hooker tries to open the door to his own room. Suddenly the door opens by itself and Hooker finds himself looking at a large Man in a food-stained undershirt.
Somethin' I can do for you?
Yeh, this is my apartment.
Used to be. They moved you out an hour ago. Seems you wasn't paid up.
I'll be damned. They got somebody to live here.
You know what they did with my clothes?
They pawned 'em to get the rent you owed.
Ha, you got the last iaugh on ‘em there, Hooker. They won't get two months' worth outa those duds. Hooker gives Eirie a look that could melt a brick.
Well I'd love to talk to you guys all right, but I gotta go decorate the den. Without further ado, he closes the door.
Hooker and Eirie start back down the stairs.
’ You ready to go see Gondorff now?
Yeah, what the hell. You got some clothes you could lend me? EIRIE . Sure, but we don't have nothin' for train tickets.
I know. Just get me a badge and I'll do the rest. No more strike- outs tonight, Eirie. Look out. Johnny Hooker is back. cut TO

We pick up Hooker and Eirie as they come into the station and fan out in different directions. Hooker is wearing Eirie's clothes, which look ridiculous on him, The pants are a good eight inches too short, and the shirt is burst ing at the seams, showing patches of skin between the: uttons.  32 33 34

We follow Birie into the gift shop where he goes to the t section. He looks enrough several small novelties until h finds what he's looking for -- a little tinh replica of a policeman's badge. He looks around for store detectives, and seeing none, slips the badge into his pocket. cut To

in another part of the station. We see him removing a sig from a door, but the angle prohibits us from being able t read it. He drops the sign in a waste can and walks out into the passenger lobby. Eirie passes him and slips him the tin badge.

After scanning the area carefully for a minute, Hooker go up to a conservative-looking Businessman, who's busy read e schedule board. Hooker flashes open his wallet to revea the little tin badge and then quickly closes it again.
Excuse me, sir. Treasury Department. I'd like to ask you a few questions. BUSINESSMAN . What for? I haven't done anything.
We don't doubt that, but there's a counterfeiting operation passing bad money in the station. Have you made any purchases here today?
(reluctantly) | well, yes, a small gift, and some ‘ood. _, HOOKER . Then I'm afraid we'll have to im- ound your money until we're sure at it's all good. Can I see your wallet please.
(handing it over) But I got a train to make.
It'll only take twenty minutes or so. You can pick it up at the window down hall.
But what about all these other people?
(blowing up) We'll get ‘em! Give us a chance. I'm not the only agent in here ya know. We go around advertisin ourselves, how many counterfeiters do you think we'd catch, huh? (pointing to his shi

‘You think I'm wearin' this rag here ‘cause I like it? Christ, everybody thi life's a holiday or somethin when you got a badge. {pouring it on I been here bor thirteen hours, Charlie, and I never knew there was so much ugliness in people. . You try to help 'em and they spit ‘on ya. I shoulda let. you gotten yourself arrested for passin' false notes. The Businessman is totally shamed.
I'm sorry, really I am, but I can't wait twenty minutes. My train leaves in ten.

All right, I'll give ya a break. (pointing to a hall Down that hall there, there's an unmarked door on the left. Go in that door and wait at the cashier window. I'll take this... (indicates _ _the money) . +;-in the back and run it through right away. We'll have ya outa there in a couple minutes.
Thank you. You don't know how much I appreciate this.
with a ittle wave) Think nothing of it. The Businessman goes off down the hall, more than gratefu for the special treatment.
Hooker, meanwhile, joins Eirie and the two spring over to buy tickets for Florida.
as we follow him down the hall to the unmarked door. He strides on through to find himself face-to-face with a wa of busily flushing urinals. cur TO

sprinting out of the train station, having seen Hooker an Eirie buying their tickets. He races up to the limousine in which Lonnegan is waiting. (out of breath) | Hey, they're takin’ a powder on the train. We better hurry if we're gonna put’ the snatch on 'em.
Let 'em go.
(in disbelief) . Let 'em go? Christ, what if they skip the country or somethin'?
They're goin' down to Florida to see Gondorff. They'll be back. All of ‘em. Floyd just looks at Lonnegan in wonderment. How does he know this kinda stuff. . cur TO  38 39 40
We pick wp Hooker and Eirie getting off the train, and winding their way through the crowd. Both are travelin light.” Hooker, of course, has no luggage at all -- jus the clothes Eirie lent him.
I gotta get some decent clothes. I can't show up at Gondorff's lookin' like this.
You got the money right on your feet there. We shoulda thought of it earlier.
(looking down at his beloved alligators) Aw, no.... cuT TO
Hooker has his alligator shoes up on the counter. The Pawnbroker looks them over with the crushing indifference that characterizes his breed.
They're alligator, ya know.
So what. We got five thousand of ‘em in the Everglades across the street.
(pissed) Not Brazilian ones. The Pawnbroker hands over a twenty dollar bill. Hooker doesn't like it, but he takes it. cuT TO

Hooker and Eirie are walking along with a copy of Gondorf letter in hand, obviously looking for an address. Hooker has on his new clothes now, and while they're none too st ish, at least they fit. They find the address they want on the curb and look up expecting to see Gondorff's house Instead they are greeted with a sign that says: FLORIDA STATE PENITENTIARY, Eirie stands there with his mouth ope Hooker is just plain disgusted.  41 42 43
A big house with a yard, huh? cur To
Hooker and Eirie sit in the visiting room awaiting the appearance of Gondorff. Hooker is barely able to control his anger. Eirie, of course, is fascinated with prison and everything in it.

A.door opens and out comes Gondorff, wearing a smile as wide as the stripes, which clothe him from head to toe. He's also wearing the fedora hat which is his trademark. GONDORFF . Howdy. Glad you could make it.
Bite off.

What the hell are you s0 sore about. I'm the one that's in jail. You remember that senator I took on a stocks deal? I got a job as a gardener in a cemetery, figurin' nobody there is gonna put finger on me. Turns out the sena- tor comes down to observe Veterans Day and I'm out there waterin' the lawn. First honest work I ever did and look what happens to me. I been here two years.
You coulda told us. +.
Then I never woulda got ya down here, I knew if you thought I was in the money, you'd come down and try to mooch some.

(incensed) I don't need your goddamn money. I jot a zinc mine in Cuba, some oil interests in Japan and a race horse that's definitely Kentucky Derby material. Not to mention the next light-heavyweight champion.
What's his name?
Typhoon Taylor.
Who sold him to ya, Jackie Pope?
Yeah, you know Jackie?

Christ, he tried to sell me the guy four years ago, only he was as cal in' him Tugboat Taylor then. Every time he loses, Jackie gives him a ue name. He's better now." vt got him fightin' a contender next week at the Jersey Gardens. I tell ya, Typhoon's got a right hand like a steam drill.
How do you know? He's never hit anything with it.
I been workin' with him personally. I used to be a Golden Gloves cham- pion, ya know.
You're a great businessman, Hooker. Did this horse you bought have all three legs?
Some day you're gonna be sorry you don't have a piece of my action.
