While Macalinski is busy toweling off his suit, Gondorff comes over and attempts to dry Macalinski's hair with a n kin. He makes one swipe, and’ suddenly Macalinski is bald

Mr. Macalinski, your hair! Macalinski reaches for the top of his head and feels only skin. He has a terrible realization as Gondorff looks in his napkin and holds up a slightly soggy hairpiece. . GONDORFF . . This is real convenient, Macalinski. We'll just send this rug out to be dry cleaned and you won't have to wash your hair. What'll they think of next? Is that your real nose? Macalinski's humiliation has given way to pure rage. He tries to snap the toupee out of Gondorff's hands.

Give me that. Unfortunately, Gondorff pulls away slightly as Macalinski grabs the hair, causing the hairpiece to split right up t middie. At this point, Gondorff lets go and calls for a waiter loud enough for the whole club hear.
Waiter, waiter! Could we get some thread over here? Mr. Macalinski seems to have a run in his wig. Macalinski motions the waiter to get lost or fear for his ife.
(with sincerity) . That's too bad. It was such a nice one too. You probably get lotsa compliments on that. ‘Course you'd think they'd give ya better glue with it.
You watch your tongue, nigger, or you'll wake up one morning without it.

Macalinski has said this with his back to Veronica so tha she hasn't heard it.- Gondorff figures maybe it's time to off for a while. Both men take their seats, as Macalinski reaches for a deck of cards in the center of the table.

(surprising]: __ composed now) I think we owe it to Miss Forrest to settle our differences like gentlemen. A simple game of skill. Macalinski puts two cards face down on the table. He then goes through the deck and pulls out the queen of diamonds He holds it up for Gondorff and Veronica to see.

The queen, in honor of Miss Forrest. He puts the queen face down on the table between the two cards, and lays the rest of the deck aside. As he does it see him slip one card up his sleeve. th . . MACALINERI I e game is s @ enough. I move the cards around. Mr. Berrigan tries to pick out the queen. If he does, he'll have the pleasure of Miss Forrest's Company alone. If not, he'll leave & club and never return. Fair enough, Berrigan.
Fair enough.
(to Veronica) . Why don't you try it once, just to show Mr. Berrigan how it's done?
All right, if you insist. Macalinski moves the cards. It's easy to follow the queen it ends up in the middle. Veronica picks it out with no rouble.

See, nothin' to it, Berrigan. Even you should be able to do it. As Macalinski takes the queen back from Veronica, he palm it and replaces it with the card up his sleeve, It's done in a movement so deft that we can only see it in slow mot Gondorff and Veronica can't possibly have seen it at all. Macalinski puts the new card face down in the middle agai with everyone assuming it's still the queen.

_All right, Berrigan, your turn. Macalinski begins moving the cards again, more quickly th time, but it's still not difficult to follow the card tha should have been the queen. It ends up in the middle agai
Well, which one is it? Gondorff studies the cards. It seems like there's no way can win. None of them are queens. Gondorff puts his hands on the two outside cards.
I'll say it's neither of these two. Before Macalinski can protest, Gondorff flips over the tw cards. Neither, of course, is the queen.

Looks like I win. The queen has got to be the other one. Macalinski does a slow burn, but there's nothing he can d He's been outfoxed. He goes to take in the non-queen that still face down, but Gondorff's hand is on it first. -
I just wanta thank the little lady before she goes back in the deck. Gondorff flips over the card. It's a four of clubs. Veron reacts with feigned shock. Macalinski tries to maintain h ignity.
Tf you'll excuse us, Miss Forrest and I have a date for dinner.
(to Veronica) . You're not really gonna go out with him, are ya?
It would be a pleasure. As Veroncia and Gondorff get up to leave, Gondorff flips dollar bill toward Macalinski.
That's for the use of the table. Keep the change. (pointing to Macalinski's Ss Maybe you can get yourself a shine. Macalinski gives Gondorff a look that could kill.
as he turns and leaves the club with Veronica on his am. He winks at Hooker as he passes his table.
as he starts back toward his own table. There's a on his shoulder. He turns around to find a very agitate: Lionel Richardson.
Excuse me, sir, I was told you were the owner. Can you tell me where the green phone 1s?
He walks away, leaving poor Richardson to make another fu search for his telephone call. cur TO
Macalinski, accompanied by three bodyguards, comes out a door of the club and walks down the pier to the amusement center. He's generally in a foul mood, and has sent the women home for the night. :

A couple of concessionaires say hello to Macalinski, but doesn't respond. As he reaches the park entrance, Hooker approaches from the side. He's dressed more working class now, complete with a Cagney beret. He adopts the speech pattern of a prizefighter.
Mr. Macalinski. Hooker gets no acknowledgement from Macalinski, but is im diately surrounded by two bodyguards. Macalinski walks on ahead.
I wanta see Macalinski. “BODYGUARD He don't wanna see nobody.

Tell him it's about Ivory Berrigan. One of the bodyguards hustles ahead to Macalinski. They h a short conference and the Bodyguard waves Hooker and the second bodyguard forward. Macalinski, however, doesn't wa for them. He continues on toward his objective.
Where are we goin'? Can't I talk to him here?
He's takin' his ride. He does it every night before he goes to bed. Says it helps him sleep.  98

Finally Macalinski reaches his destination -- the famous Parachute Jump, an awesome tower of steel reaching 300 fe into the air, culminating at the top in a brightly lit ei pronged platform. Suspended by long cables from each pron of the platform are the flimsy-looking two-seater chairs, which now dangle a few feet off the ground waiting for th next round of riders. Having no weight in them at this point, the chairs swing slightly in the breeze, sending Pinging noises up the cables which just seem to disappear in the dark sky above. Not a ride for the faint of heart. The Operator of the parachute is quite familiar with Macalinski.

Evening, Mr. Macalinski. Oughta be _ able to see all the way to Philadelphia tonight. Macalinski just nods. For the first time, he turns to fac Hooker, who has caught up by now. . MACALINSKT . You was in the club tonight, right?
Yeah, but....
{pointing to the _ Parachute chair) Get in. Hooker looks up at the tower. He's not at all sure he wan to get in that seat.
You wanna talk or don't ya? Hooker nods weakly and gets into the seat. The Operator s them in and the chair begins to rise.
The name's Florian, Bobby Florian. Hooker offers his hand. Macalinski ignores it.
What about Berrigan? HOOKER ; That thing he did with your hair and all. That wasn't no accident. :
o~
HOOKER (Cont'd) He'd been plannin' to do that as a favor for some friends of his, JoJo Berry and Will Bates, who don't like you so good, just to make you look bad in your own joint.
(sarcastically) . And you felt so bad about it, you decided to tell me so I could kill ya.
Hey, look, I got nothin' against you. I'm a fighter, not a mob gee. I just done what he tells me up to now.
Are these business interests he says he's got all fighters?
Yeah, me and a couple other guys who ain't worth shinola. He makes his dough offa my right hand. Hooker holds up a clenched right fist to demonstrate the point.
See, when I signed with this guy, he told me he was gonna bring me along right.... At this point, Hooker happens to glance down at the groun
which is now about 150 feet away. It scares the hell out im.
op FOOKER . Anyway, I win my first four fights in a row all by knockouts, three of ‘em in the first heat. So he gets me a fight with Alvarado, who's ranked number fifteen. The guy's so far

: HOOKER (Cont'd) over the hill, you can't see him no more, and Berrigan tells me I gotta throw the fight so he can pay off some markers. Take a dive in the fifth. So I'm out there, fresh as a daisy, ain't been hit with nothin' all night, and I gotta lie down. Hooker steals another quick glance at the ground.
The height is starting to get to him.
Macalinski, meanwhile, continues to take in the sights li he was looking out a train window.

So he leaves me alone the next three fights, I bust three more guys, including Frankie Carl, who ain't no bum. I take him out in the fourth. .So now I got a shot at Kelley ina week, who couldn't beat me with an axe, and Berrigan wants me to go in the water again. Every time I start gettin' someplace, he tanks me out. T ain't gonna take that no more. I coulda been eight and zero by now and fightin' high rankers.
The height is about 240 feet now and the wind is beginnin to blow the chair around a little. Hooker is struggling t maintain his cool.
That's very touching, but what do ya need me for?

If I cross Berrigan, I'm gonna need some protection. I don't take that dive, and his people '1l break my legs. They tell me you got some muscle in this town. I don't know if it's enough to handle Berrigan, but I'm willin' to take a chance.
(chuckling to himself) Don't think I got enough to handle Berrigan, huh?
I'm tellin' ya, he's no good. I seen what he's done to some people. Nobody wants to mess with him. _ _MACALINSKI ; Well, assuming I don't die of fright, what's in it for me?
Well, I got some money goin' down on this fight. I'm layin' six grand on me. I cut you in for, say, twenty percent at even odds, that's, ah....
(instantly) Twelve hundred dollars.
That oughta be worth some protection.
About fifteen minutes. . HOOKER . Okay...Fifty percent. Look, I ain't got any more. What do you say?
Macalinski ‘isn't about to say. top now.
Hooker takes a look, but *two feet He looks out over the panorama.

(pointing __ horthwest) Arnie was right. You can see Philadelphia. u ickly fixes again on a in front of his face. He really looks ba 101 102 The chair has reached the 103 oint about now. The rigid expression of one who is really scared stiff.

Suddenly the bottom drops out and the chair plunges in wh seems like free fall. So realistic was this ride that the Armed Forces used to use it to train paratroopers. The la glimpse we had of Hooker was one of sheer terror. About eighty feet from the bottom a parachute opens and slows t final stages of the descent. We:
as the seat settles down to the ground, Macalinski steps like he'd just been for a manicure. Hooker staggers out, not at all sure of his balance.
So what do ya say, Macalinski?
(walking away) : I'll think about it. What gym you train at?
Golding's on Seventh. Where should I call ya? The club?

Forget it, If I want to talk to ya, T'li get in touch with you. Hooker watches them go, leaning on a post for support. On they're safely out of sight, he stumbles over to a trash and throws up. cuT To

location: A DINER ON THE AMUSEMENT PIER

text: A typical waterfront greasy spoon with a horseshoe counte and napkin holders that dispense fortunes.

Hooker enters the diner to get something to settle his stomach. The place is pretty empty this time of night. Hooker orders a bicarbonate, While he's waiting, he happe to look across the counter just as a familiar face looks up at him. It's his old friend, Lieutenant Snyder, the Chicago bunco detective. The two men are astonished to. see each other. At first, neither of them moves from his position. -
Hi there, Hooker. Remember me?

How could I forget you, Snyder. | What are you doin' in Atlantic City, bringin' in a new disease? Snyder has long since learned to let cracks like that rol off his back. He feigns casualness, but is ready to move at the slightest hint that Hooker is going to flee. Hooke on the other hand, is finely attuned to any sign that Sny may attack. Hooker's bicarbonate is brought to him by the fountain attendant.
I'm with the federal bunco people now. Came down here to pinch a guy.
(drinking his bicarbonate) Well I hope you find him. _ SNYDER . I just did. Didn't expect him to walk right up to me though.
You're bluffin'. The feds got bigger guys to worry about than me.

Not this one. I coulda overlooked that three grand in bad notes you slipped me in Chicago, but when you played me for the chump in that Lonnegan caper, that tore it. It was ail I could do to keep Lonnegan from puttin' a bullet in me. I figure if you go up for a ten-year stretch, it might square things up.
You know it ain't gonna do no good to chase me. I've always been faster than you.
Yeah, but I got the endurance. I been waitin' four years for this.
Snyder gets up from his stool to make his move. Hooker flips a coin on the counter to pay for the_ bicarbonate a then sprints out the door with Snyder in close pursuit.

racing down the amusement midway with Snyder at his heels both dodging the street vendors and the scattered people still strolling the pier at this hour. Hooker makes for t Fun House, leaping the turnstile much to the surprise of attendant. Snyder flashes his badge as he crashes through curt TO

Like most forties fun houses, this one consists of a seri of "obstacles" that one must pass through to get out. Onc you're in the progression, you have to go on. There's no turning back. The obstacles are designed to be fun if tak at a deliberate speed. If you're in a hurry, the place ca be treacherous. Neither Hooker nor Snyder are deliberatin

The first obstacle is a revolving drum just inside the entrance tunnel. It's difficult enough to walk through. But Hooker tries to take it at a dead run. He's thrown down violently and tumbles several times, Snyder is able to grab him for an instant, but is immediately thrown off his feet too. lll ANGLE 111 The two men grapple fiercely, tumbling head over heels, banging off the walls, flailing at each other with arms a legs. Neither is able to establish dominance because of the constant revolving of the drum. Hooker finally kicks himself free and scrambles out on hands and knees. Both men have taken a terrible beating. .

head_text.subj: ANOTHER TUNNEL IN THE FUN HOUSE 112

text: Hooker jumps to his feet and heads into another tunnel, t one pitch dark. Still the two go as fast as they can, in effort to gain ground, crashing from side to side, trippi on things, knocking over the laughing clowns and roaring devils that pop out at them. :  113 114 115

head_text.subj: AT A FOUR-LANE SLIDE IN THE FUN HOUSE 113

text: Hooker emerges from the tunnel at the top of a four-lane slide. Usually one negotiates the slide by sitting on a burlap sack. Hooker disdains the sack, flinging himself down the slope head first. Both are getting skin burns to go with the bruises they got in the barrel. Neither man i having fun in this house.
Hooker has his choice of the "Slanted House" or the "Mirr Maze." A good mirror maze is truly a confounding expersen People have been known to get lost in them for upwards of an hour.

Snyder charges in after Hooker, and is brought to a quick stop by the sight of sixteen different images of himself. The pace of the chase now changes completely. Snyder makes his way slowly through the maze, painstaking trying to discern the real path from all the reflected on Every once in a while an image of Hooker will flash acros several mirrors, but Snyder has no idea which one to chas It's quiet now, the only sound, the labored breathing of two men. Hooker finally calls to Snyder from another part Q e maze. ¥
You never shoulda followed me in here, Snyder. I've been through this maze a hundred times.
It don't matter what you do, Hooker. I'm not leavin' Atlantic City with- out you.

Guess I might as well give up then. Suddenly, Hooker appears rig t off Snyder's left shoulder He cocks his arm for a punch, but Snyder catches him out the corner of his eye, whirls around, and smashes a might blow to Hooker's gut. Or what he thought was Hooker. Un- fortunately, it's just another mirror image. Hooker, beca of his experience in this maze, knew just where to stand create a single reflection. Snyder's punch splinters the mirror to bits and opens a nasty cut on his head.

Snyder is an enraged bull now. Several images of Hooker begin to appear in the mirrors. Snyder goes after all of them, wildly clubbing them with his pistol butt, kicking them with his boots, shattering mirror after mirror in a frantic attempt to destroy the real Hooker. Finally all t images of Hooker disappear, and Snyder hears his footstep receding rapidly in the distance. He knows by the time he finds his way out, Hooker will be long gone. He looks bac at the trail of destruction he's left and then slumps bac against the wall in exhaustion. We hold a beat and: cuT TO
The store is closed, but Hooker gets in with a key and go back to the "meat locker."

Gondorff, Singleton, The Big Ohio, the Tuxedo Kid and Eir are waiting for him. Gondorff has gotten out of his ivory suit, preferring, of course, his undershirt and fedora. However, he's still in his makeup. We see that it only covers from his neck up and from his wrists out. The rest of him is lily-white.
Well it took ya long enough. How'd it go? .
He didn't say much. 1 don't know how good a hook I got into him. GONDORFF . What'd he say when you told him about the Kelley fight?
Nothin'. Just kept lookin' at the scenery. Maybe he doesn't hate you - enough yet.
It's not enough for these guys to hate ya. They gotta see how they can make money offa hatin' ya. He'll figure it out.
That ain't the worst of it. I ran into Snyder tonight.
What the hell's he doin’ here? HOOKER . He's a fed now. Been failin' his way upward, but he still don't like me any better than he used to.
You think he knows what we're here for?
Naw, he came for me. Says he's gonna send me up this time.
You say the word, we all go home. None of us'd like to see you do a stretch.
Forget it. None of us likes the stretch Kid Twist is doin' either. I've stayed away from Snyder this long, I can lose him for another couple weeks.
(tired) . Okay, let's knock off for tonight. cut TO

It's late at night now and the street is about deserted. Hooker is making his way home staying in the shadows as m as possible in case Snyder may be patrolling the streets. He passes an apartment building and sees a light on ina third floor window. He stops for a second, considers it and decides to enter the building.

etting off the elevator, an old cage-type, at the third loor. He goes down the hall to door 306 and knocks. The door opens, and there stands Veronica. The radio plays Helen Forrest's "I'm Nobody's Baby."
Hooker, 70 119
Howdy. I was in the neighborhood; 1 thought I'd drop by and say you did a nice job on Macalinski tonight.
(making no move to invite him in) It was nothin'. Just another con.
If it was so nothin', why aren't you asleep yet?
Just restless, I guess. tired of standing in the doorway, walks right in, much to the chagrin of Veronica.
I didn't invite you in.
I thought you might like some company for a change. I never see you with anybody. Christ, Sheridan, how come you're so hard-nosed all the time? I mean, now that we're even Steven....
We ain't never gonna be even Steven, and if I wanted company, I woulda got some. I know ten guys I could call right now and they'd be up here inside a five minutes.

All right, I won't stay long. I know you wanna get back to not worryin!' about the con. Can I have a beer? I'll pay ya for it. Hooker goes in the icebox and gets two bottles of beer. Veronica plunks herself down on the couch, her arms cross She is restless.
Get me one too, Maybe it'll make me tired. If I didn't have to worry about Macalinski seein' me, I could go out dancin' or somethin’.
You could dance here.
Not likely. You need a partner.
You got one.
Aw, c'mon. I used to teach dancin’. I don't dance with just any shlump.
_ (infuriated) You think I can't dance? I happen to be from Chicago, sweetheart.
So am I.
You go to high school at all?
Yeah. Taft.

Taft? I went to Jefferson. Scored two touchdowns on ya in '24. Eighty- five yard punt return. Sixteen yar end run. And I was only a sophomore. If I'd ever gotten to be a junior, no tellin’ how many I mighta scored.
That don't mean you can dance. Everybody knows a Jaffie couldn't take two steps in a row.
Why would I ask ya to dance if I couldn't dance?
You didn't come over to dance. I know what you came up here for. None of the eruye at Jefferson could do that, either.

Not with a Taft broad, anyhow. You were liable to catch somethin’. {going over to .. ., the record player) Sit tight, doll. I'11 show ya who's from Chicago. Hooker searches quickly through some records and finds so thing he likes, Glenn Miller's "In The Mood." He puts it the turntable and drops the needle. He moves a couple cha out of the way to make more room as the intro starts. Veronica can't believe this. :
All right, Sheridan. Do your worst.

The beat comes up and Hooker and Veronica launch into the most knock-down, killer-diller lindy jitterbug we have ev seen, featuring all the great "air steps" and acrobatics early forties could muster. Veronica executes an amazing series of twirls, kicks and jumps that come within inches taking Hooker's head off. Hooker, on the other hand, is a great power dancer, whipping Veronica around like a top, throwing her over his back, around ‘his shoulders and und his legs. They're both dancing fluidly: but with a certai savagery -- each one trying to outdo the other, each one trying to push the dance into steps that the other can't follow. It's a slam-bang two minutes. The Soul Train All- Starts got nothin' on this. The record ends and the dance finishes in a draw. Both Ho and Veronica maintain their nonchalance, like it was a wa in the park, each trying hard to disguise the fact that t gasping for breath. Hooker chugs the last of his beer and picks up his hat.
Hope ya get some sleep.
Yeah, see ya around.

CONTINUED i121 Hooker walks quietly out the door. Once he's gone, Veronica sags into a chair, completely wo out, but not a little bit exhilerated. She'll get to slee tonight. ‘I'm nobody's baby, I wonder why. Won't someone hear my plea And please take a chance with me Because I'm nobody's baby now.'

The same room we saw him in at the beginning of the film. The photographs are still on the wall, but there's now a blank space where Kid Twists's picture once hung. One of Lonnegan's aids, Gelleher, is s owing him a flyer adver- tising the Florian (Hooker)-Kelley fight.
Looks like they're gonna use some kinda boxing scam, peddling Hooker as a fighter. I heard they tied into Macalinski last year.

Yeah, Scanlon told me about it. Gondorff played him made up like a nigger. Just the thought of what Scanlon told him starts Lonnegan chuckling, Pretty soon he's laughing almost uncontrol abl Gelleher is a little taken aback. He's never seen Lonnega like this before. (barely able to talk) . \ “You know what they did to him?
No, what? - Lonnegan is laughing so hard it takes him ten seconds to quiet down enough to tell Gelleher what Gondorff did.
They took off his toupee... (breakin up again -..and ripped it!
_ (amazed) And ripped? Lonnegan can only nod. He's convulsed with laughter again He pounds the desk with sheer glee.
Suddenly, Floyd storms into the room, obviously agitated something. He plunks a copy of the Chicago Tribune down o Lonnegan's desk. :
Doyle, look at this. That bastard Chicago DA has indicted us. Can you believe them rabbits? For tax eva- sion, the bum. That sucker's lookin! for a lead luncheon.
Don't get excited, Floyd. I knew about it a week ago, We've beat _ that rap before, we'll beat it again.
But don't you see what this does? The feds'll be all over us. We can't go around killin' Gondorff's people with that much heat on. We'll all end up in the chair.
I know all that Floyd. I've been thinkin' about it all week.
So what do we do? Just let 'em go? (getting worked up and pointing to the flyer) ‘That guy called me Mutt.
No. (pause) . We get Macalinski to kill ‘em for us.
Yeah, but we're the ones who took it in the shorts. What kinda charge do we get outa this.
Just the satisfaction of bringing off a con that goes Gondorff one better than he gave us. As good as his game was, it only took our money. So Macalinski pulls the triggers. Dead is dead.
Not to me, it ain't. A guy is always deader when I kill: him. How do you know Macalinski'll do it? :
Don't worry about Macalinski. I'll give him a reason. There's only one guy in this world I fear more than him.
Who's that?
Me. This last remark is lost on Floyd. He's totally absorbed the flyer on Hooker's fight.
Christ, Mutt and Jeff. I hate fuckin' Mutt and Jeff. If I was in the ring with this guy, I'd punch him a new ace. cur TO

detailing Hooker's somewhat reluctant training for the Ke fight. We see shots of him: 1. skipping rope; 2. shadow boxing in front of a mirror; 3. practicing his crossing punches on the ‘punch catchers' held by The Big Ohio; 4. working the speed bag. He has a little trouble with this last one, as his timing is not yet sharp. All of this training is done under the supervision of The Ohio, who seems to be very knowledgeable about fighting.

We come out of the montage with Hooker throwing combinati into the heavy bag. lorff (in black face and the ivory suit) and The Big Ohio are watching him. Hooker is sweati profusely and obviously getting a little tired. The rest the gym is filled with confidence men, all dressed out as fighters and trainers, but at this point, they're just si ting around shooting the breeze.
(gasping) How much longer?
(looking at his stopwatch) Minute and a half.
That's too long. Hooker drops his arms and stops punching GONDORFF ‘ C'mon, you'll never get in shape that way.
What difference does it make? I'm gonna be down anyway.
Yeah, but you gotta make it look good. Macalinski’s gonna know somethin's wrong if you fast go out there and get pulverized.
How good is this guy Kelley?
(mimicking Hooker ) . What difference does it make? You're gonna lie down anyway. HOOKER . Yeah, but I wanta lie down with my head on.

Then keep hittin' the bag. Suddenly Eirie comes rushing into the gym. . .. EIRIE . Macalinski just drove up outside. GONDORFF . Okay, everybody, let's get movin’! Immediately all the previously inert confidence men sprin their feet and begin the various rigors of training. Some work the speed bags and heavy bags, some get rubdowns, ot shadowbox. The Tuxedo Kid takes up a position next to Gondorff, dressed in a gaudy, checkered sport coat. We know this disguise is causing him great pain.
Ohio, get in the ring and spar a few rounds with Hooker. And Ohio.... h THE BIG OHIO Yeah?
Get hit a lot.

Hooker and The Big Ohio quickly put on their protective h lear and jump into the ring. Macalinski enters the gym wi ee of the bodyguards, He surveys the scene a second and then spots Hooker sparring in the ring. He comes over to watch, standing a couple feet behind Gondorff and the Tux Kid, who pretend not to know he's there. Up in the ring, Hooker is punching The Big Ohio all over lot, The Big Ohio, of course, exaggerating the impact of every blow. Finally Hooker delivers a left hook, and The Big Ohio, in a tour de force of acrobatics, flips over th ropes and clean out of the ring. Gondorff calls Hooker an pretends to be furious with hin.

What the hell do ya think you're doin'? I told you not to show that left hook. What if some sports- writer had seen that? You think they'd ever believe you could lose to Dann Kelley on the square with a left hook like that?
I'm sorry. I just forget my self. None of this has been lost on Macalinski's ears. The Big meanwhile, is staggering to his feet.
(dazed) Sorry Berrigan, I've had enough.

Yeah, all right. (shouting up to Hooker) . Bobby, that's enough for a while. Hooker climbs out of the ring and winks as he walks past Macalinski. Gondorff turns around and for the first time is face to face with Macalinski. 4 _  GONDORFF . Well, if it ain't Macalinski. You ever find that Queen?
Yeah, it was in my sleeve. (indicating Gondorff's suit) I found it ‘cause I change my clothes now and then.
o~ 125 CONTINUED - 3 125

Oh, this isn't the same suit you saw me in. I got seven or eight of these. Macalinski didn't resally come to talk fashion. MACALINSKI . Your boy looks pretty good, Berrigan. GONDORFF . Yeah, doesn't he though. Let me give you a tip Macalinski. Don't tell . anybody ‘cause I wanna keep the odds down, but this kid is gonna murder Kelley. You'd be smart to get some money down on him.
I wouldn'ta thought you'd be so interested in puttin’ me onto a good thing.

I believe in lettin’ bygones by bygones, a know what I mean? I don't mind oo loin’ guys like you a favor. 1 figure you can use a break now and then. I wouldn't steer you wrong, Macalinski. you can't lost with a bundle on this id.
Is that right? Thanks, Berrigan. I appreciate it. {with sarcasm, sweeping his hand around the gym) - Well, I'll leave ya to tend to all your various business interests.
Yeah, by the way, Lola sends her love. Macalinski suppresses the urge to strangle Gondorff, and leaves the gym with his guard dogs. On the way out, he passes Hooker toweling off.
(out of the side o of his mouth) Meet me at the Bluebird tonight at nine o'clock.
Hooker nods, and Macalinski disappears down the stairs. Gondorff looks over to Hooker for some sign. Hooker gives him both thumbs up. cur TO
We pick up Hooker walking through the club and back to. Macalinski's office. He knocks on the door.
One of Macalinski's goons opens it and immediately yanks Hooker inside and throws him up against a wall.
What is this?

We called the Jersey Boxing Commission, they never heard of Bobby Florian. HOOKER . . That's ‘cause I done all my fightin’ in California. . (pulling a piece of paper out of his wallet Here, here's my license. Macalinski looks it over carefully, and then puts it in h pocket.
_ (to his goon) All right, let him go. Hooker sinks into a chair opposite Macalinski's desk, sti little shaken.
Your owner is even lower than I thought he was. He tried to get me to put money on you, even though he's told ya to take a dive.
That's 'cause he wants ya to lose your shirt.

How much is he puttin' on Kelley? HOOKER . Two hundred grand maybe. That ain't the only way he wins though. Remember the guy in the checked coat that was with ‘im in the ? That's Harry Chandler, his bookie friend. The odds on the fight are dead even all over town, except Harry's givin' two- to-one on Kelley to get people to bet on me at his book.
Does he know you're supposed to dump the fight?

Hell, yes. He builds up a big bunch a bets on me and he and Berrigan split the take. Berrigan gets it comin' and goin' and I don't get nothing but a_ one line story that says Bobby Florian went on his butt when Danny Kelley breathed on him too hard. Berrigan takes it on the lam to the Bahamas and I wind up sellin' pencils. I tell ya, if I don't throw s fight, it's gonna cost Chandler and Berrigan plenty.
And whoever bets on you at Chandler's odds is gonna win plenty. . HOOKER . That's right. That's what I'm doin' with my dough. i'm havin' a friend bet it, of course.
All right, Florian, I wanta see ya fight.
You saw me fight today.
I mean against somebody good. HOOKER . Why? All I'm askin' for is protection.
You ain't gonna get any unless I see you fight.
But that's impossible. Berrigan'll never let me fight before the Kelley match.
He won't know about it. We'll do it at another gym. :
What if I get cut or somethin'?

You won't if you're any good, and if you ain't, you might as well take that dive anyway. I'l] pick you up to- morrow morning at ten. The bus station. Hooker wants to protest some more, but he's hustled out o the room before he gets a chance.
He walks through the club, wondering what the hell to do cur TO
Hooker comes out of the club and starts walking up the st when he catches sight of someone getting out of a car up It's Snyder. Hooker turns and takes off down the pier. Sn immediately gives chase.
Hooker heads for the "Cyclone Racer", the giant roller co He hops in the first car, which is empty, and shouts to t operator, whom he knows well.
Get this baby goin', Georgie. And do me a favor. Give me a slow-down on the seventh turn.
You got it, Hooker.  131 132 133 134 135

Georgie activates the tow mechanism and the car starts it slow ascent of the first hill as Snyder arrives. He con- siders getting in a car and going after Hooker, but then thinks better of it. He's no fool, that Snyder.

(to himself) Oh no ya don't, Hooker. You're not suckerin' me into this one. (to Georgie) Hey buddy, these cars have gotta come right back to here, don't they? There's no other place then can go, right?
That's right, Jack.
(breaking into a smile) You hung yourself this time, Hooker. He leans back against the railing, in delicious anticipat of Hooker's return. We:

barrelling down the chutes and whipping through the curve the Cyclone Racer. It's a helluva ride and the camera sho take it for a while. Suddenly, as the car is reaching the of another hill, we: cur TO
which slow appreciably as it goes into the turn. Hooker j out and grabs onto the wooden scaffolding as the car bare makes it around the corner and starts down the hill. cuT To
He release the lever, and we see a hint of a smile on his face, which is a first for Georgie. We:
climbing down the outside of the scaffolding. None of thi is visible to Snyder through the maze of track and wood t makes up the rollers coaster. Finally we: Cut TO  136 137

as it comes around the last turn and slows into the loadi area. Snyder watches it all the way in. We see his face turn to putty. He can't believe the car is empty Once it's stopped, he frantically searches under and ind every seat for some sign of Hooker. Finally he turns to Georgie
What happened to the guy that was in here?

(completely deadpan) Probably fell off and killed himself. Snyder knows Georgie's screwed him some way, but he doesn know - He turns to go look for Hooker and finds himself face to face with Floyd. Eveni ynde: Doyle L ‘d ening, S' re @ Lonnegan like a few words with ya. snyder manages a weak nod.
Snyder is ushered in by Floyd and Gelleher. He's a little unsettled by the pictures on the wall.
Hello, Snyder. What are you doin’ in Atlantic City?
I'm on vacation. Got a couple weeks, thought I'd....
{cutting him off) You shouldn't tell me lies like that, Snyder, when things between us are 80 sore. Floyd saw you chasin' Johnny Hooker.
Okay, I was.chasin' him. I came down here to take him back to Chicago. To face trial for connin'
SNYDER (Cont'd) you. I should think that would make you happy. Fat chance.
I want you to lay off Hooker. He's workin’ a con here that's gonna make me back all the money he ever took from me. I don't want anything to discourage him.
Hey look, I'm a fed now, I can't just turn my back on this stuff.

All right, then we'll make you a deal. You leave Hooker alone and I'll tell you where they're going to split up the score. That way you can come in and pinch all of 'em -- the biggest confidence bust in New Jersey history. Snyder tries to play the brinksman.
I don't know. I'11 think about it.
(in no mood for further negotiation) There's nothin' to think about. You either take the deal, or go after Hooker and hope you get him before one of my guys gets you.
You can't muscle me. I got the U.S. Government behind me.
I don't care if you got the U.s. Marines behind you. You screw up this con and all your government service'll get you is a nice funeral. Snyder decides maybe he'll soften his line a little.
How do you know when they're gonna make the split?
I got my sources.
All right. 1'11 play ball. (with false bravado) But you better come up with that info. Snyder turns and walks out the door. Lonnegan lets him go He's not expecting anymore trouble. cur To
The lights in the gyn are off as Hooker and Eirie walk th to the lighted office section. .
Gondorff lies stretched out on a couch -- his hat on his He stirs and sits up as Hooker and Eirie enter.
What happened tonight?
I had to lam it from Snyder again. He's got that pier staked out on me.
All right, then, stay off of it from now on. What about Macalinski?
He threw us a curve. He wants to see ~ me fight somebody other than the Ohio. I don't know who it is, but he's takin' me to another gym to- morrow.
Christ, after we go to all the trouble to build one of our own.
What are we gonna do?
Well, I wouldn't worry too much about it. We oughta be able to come up with something. We can tell by Gondorff's look that, at this point, he ha no idea what that might be. We hold a beat, and:
We see Macalinski looking over the boxing license he took from Hooker the night before. Under the name California Boxing Commission, he sees a phone number. He picks up th phone and dials it. cuT To
answering a phone. Intercut with Macalinski as necessary.
Hello, California Boxing Commission. MACALINSKi Yeah, I'd like some information on a guy named Bobby Florian.

Hold on one moment, please. 1'1) transfer you to the Records Department. - Billie pushes the button down a couple times to indicate she's transferring the call, and then comes on the line again with a different voice.
(most officiously) Miss Deering, Records Department.
I'd like to know what you got on a Bobby Florian. He's a middleweight.
Just a minute, please. Billie holds a few beats and then pretends to be reading from a file. .
Florian, Bobby. Age twenty-seven. Height six feet. Weight....
(impatient) Skip all that. What's his record?

His record? Let me look down here. Twelve wins, eight by knockout as an amateur. No losses. As a profes- sional, seven wins all by knockout, and one defeat. That was to Benny Alvarado at the Olympic Auditorium on the 16th of July last year.
Thanks lady, that'll do it. Macalinski hangs up and turns to the bodyguard who slamme Hooker up against the wall.
He's on the level. cuT TO
She hangs up the phone and gives the okay sign to Gondorf who's been in the room with her the whole time. curt To
Hooker is standing on the corner as Macalinski's limousin pulls up. The door is opened and Hooker gets in. He's carrying a gym bag with all his boxing gear in it.
The car pulls away as Hooker settles in beside Macalinski
How do you feel today, kid?
Fine.

Good. (pointing to a bruiser on the other side of him) I'm puttin' ya in with Tony here. Tony Savitt, meet Bobby Florian. Tony used to be the number one middleweight contender. He'll give ya a tussle.
Tony flashes Hooker a wide smile. We can tell he's ready to give Hooker more than a tussle. Hooker tries to smile back, but his mouth is a little dry and it's hard to stre it.
Where we gonna fight?

The Eighth Street Gym. It's outta the way. Hardly anybody goes there. Hooker nods and casually puts his arm out of the window l he's going to rest his hand on the roof. Instead we see h hold up two fingers. cuT To
following behind Macalinski. Eirie is driving. Gordorff i also in front, The Big Ohio in the back.

(eyes glued to Hooker's . hand) Two fingers. That's the Eighth Street Gym. Step on it, Eirie. Gondorff then puts his arm out the window, turns to the r and waves two fingers at the cars following him. We see that at least eight of them are filled with confidence sk dressed out, as usual, as boxers and trainers. cuT To
Hooker is going through his gym bag, making sure he's got everything. He pulls out a boxing shoe. The laces are completely frazzled.

(to the driver) Stop at this five and dime up here, will ya. I gotta get some new laces for these things. The driver looks to Macalinski to see if it's okay. Macalinski shrugs and nods his head. As the car pulls ove Gondorff's car goes speeding by. :
What's Hooker doin'?
Giving us a little more time.
A car pulls up in front of the gym. Billie and Singleton get out carrying a large portrait camera. Gondorff's car leads the rest of his armada around to the rear of the building.

Billie goes inside while Singleton sets up his camera out front. She asks for the owner of the place and is shown i the office of a paunchy old hacker named Pyle. Pyle has t Customary pretention of one who has nothing to be pretent out.
Hello, I'm from Life Magazine. I called you earlier?
I don't remember no call.

But you must. We're doing an eight- page spread on the great boxing gymnasiums in the country. I thought sure it was this one... (pause) Maybe it's that one across town. Turner's Gym. Pyle is not about to let this opportunity get away. The Eighth Street Gym is not exactly world famous. It's not even city famous.

Naw, this is the right one, lady. Turner's is a dump. I remember you now. We've had more champions outta here than you can shake a stick at. Ain't that right, Egan? Egan is Pyle's mousy little assistant.
(trying to remember one) Oh yeah, lots of ‘em.
Good. I'd like to get started right away. If you could get everybody out in front of the gym, I'd appreciate it. Sort of using the gym as a back- drop. .
Why do we need everybody?
That's the way we did it for the Main Street Gym in Los Angeles and Paterson's in Philadelphia.
(impressed as 11) Jees, we're gonna be in there with the Main Street and Paterson's?
Well, I guess if they can do it, we can.
Don't worry, Mr. Pyle, you'll be right out in front.
Okay, Egan, get everybody out.
We'll also need some jump ropes.
Egan rushes into the gym.
Okay, everybody, drop what you're doin' and come on out front. We're gonna have our pictures in Life Magazine. And bring your’ ropes.

There's some grumbling and complaining, but everyone file out. Once the gym is cleared, Gondorff and his men pour i through the rear door and immediately fill the place with activity. . cut To  151 152 153
They're getting near the gym.
Hold it.
What for? The car comes to a jolting stop.
I know the door guard out front. We don't want him blabbin' to Berrigan. Use the alley.
(to his driver) Do what he says.
The driver pulls down the alley and into the back of the thus prohibiting them from seeing what's going on out fro

Hooker, Macalinski, Savitt and the bodyguards enter throu the rear door. They are, of course, met with the sight of fighters training everywhere. Gondorff comes over to gree them: Because Macalinski has never seen him without black face, he wouldn't recognize him. Gondorff also alters his voice slightly.
Can I help you? I'm the- manager here, Lonny Pyle.
We'd like to use your ring for a bit. (pointing ~ to Hooker) I wanna test this boy here a little.
Well, we got the number three middle- weight contender in here. He's lookin' for some work. Why don't you throw your boy in with him?
(indicating Savitt) No, I brought my own guy.
Gondorff had not expected this. Both he and Hooker are looking a little pale right now.
Yeah. He shouts over to The Big Ohio, who's disguised in a hair piece and moustache.

Hey, Joey... (indicating Savitt) ++.tape this guy up, will ya. (indicating Hooker) I'll tape the other guy. The Big Ohio walks off to one dressing room with Savitt. Gondorff and Hooker go off to the other one, followed by Eirie.
What the hell we gonna do now?
_ Just leave it to me. Okay, Eirie, get that other guy's mouthpiece out of his bag and bring it to me. Eirie leaves to carry out his assignment as Gondorff snap a role of tape. We: cur To

Singleton has got his first shot posed. The fighters are lined up in a row, with their dukes up and menacing sneer their faces. Behind them stand the trainers, each with a towel over his arm and one hand on his fighter's shoulder Out in front of all this stands Pyle, his arms dramatical crossed, the moulder of men. Next to him is Egan, sportin the most shit-eating grin we've ever seen. Singleton ducks under the black cloth, tells everybody to still and snaps his picture. Some of the fighters turn to back into the gym, but Billie stops them.
Okay, now we'll do an action one. The fighters shake their heads, but they cooperate. cUuT TO  155 156 157

Gondorff is busily taping Hooker's hands. Much to Hooker' amazenent, he pulls out a roll of nickels and tapes that looker's fist. You can't do this for a real fight. They always check the tape. Believe me, if he runs into that hand, he'll stay down.

Yeah, but what am I supposed to do with everything he's owin' while I'm waitin' for him to run into it? Eirie bursts into the room with Savitt's mouthpiece. GONDOREF . There's a bottle of methyl chloride over there. Let the mouthpiece soak in it a while, Once Savitt gets some of that in him, he won't e able to walk let alone fight. We go to Hooker. He has his doubts. a . cut TO

Billie is rehearsing her action shot. It calls for all of fighters to skip rope in unison, under the watchful eye o their trainers while Pyle and Egan, of course, maintain t standard poses out front. None of this is visible from inside, because, like all gymnasiums, the windows are fro Billie gives the signal to begin and all the fighters sta skipping, but several are out of sync. Billie stops them.

No, no, no. Let's try it again. And remember, it's gotta be together. On the beat now. Ready. One, two, three.... They all begin skipping again. This time only one guy is out of step. The bther fighters give hin holy hell. “They tired and y wanna get s thing right, dammit. cuT TO
Hooker and Savitt, their gloves and protective headgear o are entering the ring. Macalinski settles back to watch.
(to Savitt) You got a mouthpiece?

Couldn't find it. Don't make no difference, I won't need it. Sorry pal, nobody fights in this gym without a mouthpiece. Eirie get this boy a gourbp ioe. ‘ Eirie, of course, produces the one that's been soaking in methyi chloride. Gondorff jams it into Savitt's mouth, wh winces at the taste. . . _SAVITT . Christ, this thing tastes terrible.

That's just the antiseptic we use. What would you rather have, tuber- culosis? Savitt is pretty sure he'd rather not have tuberculosis. begins to do a little shadowboxing as does Hooker on the other side. Even as he dances, Savitt begins to shake his head a little, as if to clear it. Gondorff decides it's t start. He claps his hands and the two fighters come out. Hooker immediately begins dancing away from Savitt, reali that Savitt is getting groggy. Savitt stalks him and whip out a few combinations, but Hooker is staying so far away that they do no damage.
What's the matter, you scare of me, Florian?

Just wanna give my legs some work before I put you away. Hooker continues to back away as Savitt stalks him all ov the ring. Macalinski doesn't like what he's seeing. . MACALINSKI . c'mon, Florian, fight, for chrissake. Savitt decides he's had enough of this, too. He backs Hoo into a corner and comes in to finish him off. Unfortunate the methyl chloride is really getting to him now. He: thr

two wild haymakers which miss Hooker by a foot. Savitt is shaking his head and blinking his eyes now. He looks read to fall asleep. Realizing his opportunity, Hooker steps inside and smashes the right to Savitt's stomach. Savitt doubles up, although he was probably getting ready to fal down anyway. Then Hooker cranks up and unleashes his hard right to Savitt's chin. Savitt goes down and out like a l Macalinski is amazed. He comes up to Hooker as he starts untie his gloves. _. MACALINSKI . Nice work, kid. I didn't know you had that kinda power. Get your- self a shower and we'll go.
Don't need a shower. Didn't even work up a sweat. I'll just get the gloves off and be right out. As Hooker goes off to the dressing room, Gondorff comes o to Macalinski.

I been in this business thirty years and I ain't never seen a guy with a punch like that. Where'd you find that kid? Macalinski isn't talking. He just smiles and walks away. Meanwhile the bodyguards are dragging Savitt out to the c Once they're all outside, Gondorff turns to all the gang a more than satisfied smile.
emerging from the back door and getting into the limousin
Savitt is propped up in the back seat.
How's Savitt?
He's awake, but he still don't know where he is. The limousine pulls out and we: cur TO  159 160 161 162

head_text.subj: THE FRONT OF THE GYM AGAIN 159

text: Billie is ready for yet another run-through. We can tell troops are restless. BILLIE . All right, everybody. We'll try it just once more. This is the time we get it right, okay? One, two, three.... The fighters once again begin skipping madly. This time, however, it's perfect. Fifteen grown men s: pping their a off in perfect time, each rope coming around at the same each man jumping up and down in the same rhythm. It's a t tally ridiculous sight.
Singleton snaps the pictures as Billie notices Gondorff a the others driving away.
Okay, guys, that's a keeper. Thanks for your cooperation.
The fighters and trainers drag back into the gym. Singlet folds up his camera and he and Billie start for their car Pyle, however, buttonholes them.
When's this spread gonne hit the stands? BILLIE . In a couple weeks. You be watchin’ for it
Be sure you spell my name right. It's Pyle. P+Y-L-E. Billie nods. She'll be sure and get that right.
as it moves through the city.
You got your protection Florian. Do what you want to Kelley.
Kelley'll be ever easier than Savitt here.
The limousine pulls up in front of the bus terminal and H gets out.
One more thing. Where do I find- this guy Chandler?
One eighteen North Cumberland. Ask to see some Webster jade.
See ya at the fights. The limousine pulls away from the curb. Savitt is coming of it somewhat now.
Seemed to me like I was goin' down before he even hit me.
(humoring him) Sure, Tony, sure. cur TO

Vernoica is sitting quietly on the couch, sipping some te listening to Mary Lou Williams' version of "He's Funny Th Way. . 'I never had nothin! No one to care That's why I seem To have more than my share. I got a man : Who's crazy for me He's Funny That Way.'
There's a knock at the door. Veronica goes to answer it. seems almost excited about who might be there. She opens
door to find Macalinski and two of his goons standing in Obviously, this wasn't who she was hoping for.
Just wanted to give you my personal regards, Lola. I woulda done it sooner, but it took a while to find you.

With that, he drives a vicious punch into Veronica's stom As she stumbles forward, he rears back and blasts her in face, knocking her all the way across the room and over a table. She lies unconscious on the floor. We hold on her as the lights go out, the door closes and we hear footste disappear down the stairs. We're left with the plaintive notes of Mary Lou Williams' piano. cur To

Hooker's doing much the same thing Veronica has been doin only in accordance with his tastes, he's drinking beer an listening to something a little more upbeat. Something li Liltin' Martha Tilton's "The Lady is a Tramp." Suddenly, Hooker gets a knock on his door. Unlike Vernoica, he imme ately expects the worst. Unlike Veronica, he doesn't get He opens the door and she staggers in, her nose swollen o one side and a huge shiner on her right eye.
Jesus, what happened to you?
the couch) . I forgot to put on my makeup. This is the way I really look.
(in no mood for flippancy) Who was it, Veronica? oo, VERONICA Macalinski. He thinks I oughta be payin' more attention to him. You think I could have a beer? You owe me one.
(offering his) Here, finish this one.
Veronica takes a long, slow drink. Hooker just gazes at h a minute. She becomes aware of it.

What are you lookin' at? HOOKER ; I don't know. I'm just surprised you came over here, that's all. I mean, you coulda called one of your ten guys. VERONICA . I would of, but I don't really like any of 'em and you were closer. Some- times on a night like this, you wonder if everybody else doesn't like you as much as you don't like them. (pause) How about it, Hooker? How much don't you like me? Veronica asks this question with real concern. She's not being coy. Hooker leans forward and kisses her tenderly o all the bruised areas of her face. He doesn't like her ju fine. Veronica is not at all upset by this response.
You think I could stick around here a while?
How long?
Just until I get proper medical attention.
What if I said no?

(lying) I'd find somebody else. She reaches up for his head and brings it down to her. Th kiss with all the longing of strangers and the intimacy o lovers, for what will obviously not be the last time toni 'I_get too hungry for dinner at eight I like the theatre but never come late. I never bother with people I hate. That's why the Lady is a Tramp.
I don't like crap games with barons and earls . . Won't 99 to Harlem in ermine and pearls. Won't dish the dirt with the rest of the girls. . That's why the Lady is a Tramp.'

Macalinski's limousine pulls up outside a one-story build that has Chandler Import Co. written on its front window. Macalinski, carrying a large leather bag, goes inside wit his usual compliment of bodyguards, and is greeted by a receptionist. It's Billie.
May I help you?
Yeah, I'd like some Webster jade.
You'll have to see Mr. Chandler’ about that. Second door on your , right.

Macalinski and his boys go through a door with Chandler's name on it. The Tuxedo Kid is inside, once again decked o in that checked sport coat. His office however is well ordered and rather fancy, as befits his status as an "importer."
(offerin s hand Chandler. My name's Macalinski.
Oh yeah, didn't I see you in Goldings’ Gym once?

Yeah, I was down there to have a look at Bobby Florian. I'd like to put a little money on him. They tell me you're in a betting mood. . TUXEDO KID . ‘I'm giving two to one against him. I don't think the kid's got a chance. How wrong do you think I am?
Macalinski opens his leather bag. It's bursting with mone
About four hundred grand worth.

That's a lotta potatoes, Macalinski. Most books wouldn't take that bet, but then most books aren't sporting men either. Me, I like to live - dangerous. I take risks the others won't take, ‘cause that's what life is all about, ain't it, Macalinski? Macalinski is disgusted by this false declaration of cour 2 but he grits his teeth and says:
Yeah, that's what it's all about all right. : The Tuxedo Kid leans forward and speaks into an intercom his desk.

Jerry, I'm sending in a Mr. Macalinski with a big bet on Florian. Take his money and give him a-free drink. He's a real sportsman. The Tuxedo Kid shows Macalinski to a door in the back of office. The two shake hands. TUXEDO KID. Nice to meet ya, Mr. Macalinski. Come back and see us again. Macalinksi and his boys go through the door.

They find themselves in a plush betting parlor, complete odds board, telephone operators, cashier's window and bar It's similar to the one Gondorff set up in "The Sting" on on a smaller scale, and instead of pictures of horses it features pictures of fighters. Macalinski's boys are im- pressed.
Gee, this guy's pretty well set up.
He won't be after tonight. cur TO
The suitcases are snapped open. Each one is filled to the brim with hundred dollar bills. Camera back to reveal Lonnegan and Floyd,
There it is. A million bucks. This guy Kelley better be a sure bet. I'd hate to see that kinda green disappear.
We'll find out in a few minutes. Scanlon's on the phone in the other room. There's a knock on the door, and immediately Lonnegan clo the cases. A Guard pokes his head in. Snyder's here.
Send him in. Synder swaggers in with the self-importance typical of hi
I assume you're here for your information.
That's right. Toni t's the night. 1 called eight agents into town for this bust. They're gonna be pretty burned up if I don't deliver.

You can relax, Snyder, I never go back on a. deal. ‘There's a Chinese market down Vermont near 6th. In the back are three meat lockers. The middie one isn't a meat locker at all. It's a meeting room. That's where they're gonna make the split. Snyder is amazed that Lonnegan could discover such a well organized hideout.
You mind tellin’ me how you find out stuff like this?
I got a source.
Think I could use it sometime?
Why don't you ask for yourself? (calling into e other room) Scanlon. “you off the phone yet? We hear a Voice 0.s. as another figure enters the room.
Yeah, what is it? The Voice is familiar. The camera moves to reveal that th person is even more familiar. To our amazement, it's Vero
Lonnegan delights in Snyder's surprise that the source is woman.
(making the introduction) Camille Scanlon, Agent Snyder. Snyder says he'd like to make use of your services someday.
(the ice maiden) All it takes is money.
(referring to her shiner Looks like you paid a price for what you found out.
(hard as nails) - I'll get whatever I paid back, and then some.

(taking his leave . Well, Lonnegan, it was nice doin’ business with ya. Someday when I'm bureau chief, maybe I can return the favor. (reluctantly) You know, it's too bad we're on opposite sides of the law. The government could use a guy like you. Lonnegan smiles. He's real thrilled that Snyder thinks so highly of him. Once Snyder's out the door, Lonnegan turns to Veronica.
What's the word on Macalinski?

He went for four hundred grand on Hooker. Hooker just told me on the phone that he's dumpin' the fight as soon as it doesn't look too phony. You can put your million on Kelley any time you want. Lonnegan is really proud of himself now.

You see how it all works now, Floyd? At even money, we not only get back the five hi ed grand we lost, but we get another half million in the bargain. Meetin' Henry Gondorff turns out to be the best thing that ever happened to us.

Well, I gotta get ready to go to the fight with Gondorff. You owe me a hundred grand Lonnegan. I'11 be leavin' early. I don't wanta be caught with Gondorff's boys when Macalinski sees Hooker take the count. Without hesitation, Lonnegan reaches into his desk, pulls out the money and hands it to her. She counts it quickly.
You earned every penny of it. I wish I had ten more like you. Veronica smiles at Floyd, who didn't appreciate this last comment too much.

» (heading . for the door) | Enjoy yourselves tonight. If I'm even in Chicago, I'll drop by and you can tell me about it. Lonnegan nods good-bye and Veronica is let out the door. Floyd is struggling hard with a thought.
There's still one thing I don't get. How come you told Snyder where they're gonna be meetin'?

‘Cause there's no chance they'll ever get there. Macalinski'll see to that once I tell him they conned him. (savoring the thought ) . Of course, that won't be until it's too late for him to deny it. Come on. Lonnegan picks up one of the suitcases, Floyd the other, they exit.
Although an improvement over the Jersey Garden, the Still is no fabulous forum.
Hooker is having his hands taped by The Big Ohio. Gondorf looks on, made up as Ivory Berrigan again. Eirie is pacin around the room, more nervous than anybody.
How do you feel?

Ladies and gentlemen. Welcome to tonight's program of boxing at the Stillman Auditorium. We begin a seven round semimain. On my right, wearing the red trunks and weighing in at 172, that fine Irish puncher, Danny Kelley. Cheers for Kelley as he makes his rounds.
And to my left in the black trunks and weighing in at 171, the kid from California, Bobby Florian. Hooker dances out into the ring, hands held above his hea
Floyd is disgusted.
Look at the bum jumpin' around. Like he was actually gonna make a fight of it, the cake-eater.
C'mon, Floyd. It's time to give Macalinski the bad news.
You better talk fast. Hooker may not last more than thirty seconds.
The referee has finished giving instructions to the fight as Lonnegan makes his way over to where Macalinski is sit  184 185

The bell rings and the fighters come out. Hooker's plan i obvious immediately -- to stay as far away from Kelley as possible. Kelley, however, bores right in and whips out t jabs which gnap Hooker's head back, but Hooker narrowly manages to duck the right cross that follows. IN THE STANDS - ON MACALINSKI 185 — up in the stands, Macalinski looks on tensely, as Lonnega slides in next to him.
Howdy, Carlo.
Lonnegan. What are you doin' here?
Just takin' a little vacation in the sun. Who you got your money on?
Florian. He's a hell of a puncher.
How much you got on him?
Four hundred grand. Lonnegan whistles in mock surprise.
(defending his be I've seen him. I know what he can do.
So do I. He conned me outta five hundred grand four years ago.
(incredulous What are you talkin’ about?
He's no fighter. Never has been. Name's Johnny Hooker. He's been a grifter around Chicago for years.
_LONNEGAN (Cont'd) He's goin' on his hynie here in a couple minutes. MACALINSKI . But what about his manager, Berrigan?
That's Henry Gondorff, one of the all-time greats. Not only is he not a manager, he's not even a Negro. That's just makeup. You been had, Macalinski.
Are you sure it's the same guys?

Positive. I'll never forget those two as long as I live. If I wasn't under indictment, I'd ice 'em myself as soon as the fight's over, which shouldn't be too long now. Macalinski can't believe it. He just sits there in stunne silence.

A pattern has developed in the fight. Hooker, surprisingl has one advantage. He's faster than Kelley, but Kelley ke coming at him, throwing punch after unch -- jabs, combina tions, round-houses, upper cuts, hooks, eve ing. Hooker is able to dodge three-fourths of them but the one-fourth manage to land are beginning to take a toll.

Looks like Hooker's gettin' ready to go home and spend some of your money. — Whatever doubts Macalinski may have had about Lonnegan's story are now dispelled. His astonishment is turning to cold fury. He turns to two of his bodyguards.
Grimes and Rossavich, get over to that bookie's and get our money back.
You're wastin' your time. The bookie is probably in with them. He won't even be there.

{to his men) . Get over there anyvay. And if he is there, bring him with ya. The two goons hustle off. . _. LONNEGAN . Funny, isn't it. You wouldn't think lightning would strike twice like this, I mean, especially with you knowing what happened to me an all. Ab well, I guess we all have our blind spots. | (getting up to go) | Well, I'll be seeing you, Carlo. Sorry I had to be the one to tell you. (turning back) Oh, and Carlo, 1 won't breathe a word of this to anybody. Your secret's good with me. Lonnegan walks off up the aisle, laughing to himself. Macalinski just sits in his chair and steams. curt TO

is bobbing and weaving like crazy in an effort to escape Kelley's avalanche of blows. He is able to hit Kelley fro time to time, but whenever he trades with him, he gets th worst of it. Hooker uses everything he knows to protect himself. He clinches, covers up, moves constantly and flurries his way out of corners, but Kelley 15 such a dervish that Hooker is still taking a lot of shots.

Finally, Kelley traps Hooker ‘in a corner and begins to f away like crazy. Hooker dodges this way and that, but he' getting tag ed and he's unable to get away. A cut opens over his left eye and his legs begin to wobble a little.  190 191 192 193 194 195

crash through the front door, which is locked and into Chandler's office which isn't. :  196 197 198 199 200 201

Hooker's in trouble as he's slowing down and Kelly is sco more frequently. Kelley connects with three wicked body s and a left to the head that sends Hooker reeling into the ropes. Instead of bouncing away, he just stays there, his legs too tired to move him.
Even his flurry tactics don't slow Kelley, who wades in a unleashes another barrage. Hooker can do nothing but try weather it. He gives up all pretense to offense. It's pur a matter of survival now.

calls on all the defensive quickness he can muster, movin his head, slowing blows with the forearms and shoulders, ducking, bobbing and leaning back over the ropes. Almost like Ali's rope-a~dope. Kelley, meanwhile, just keeps. banging away, Hooker takes it and takes it and takes it, and finally just sags to the canvas. The count gets to eight and the bell rings.

Eirie and The Big Ohio drag Hooker back to his corner and immediately apply the water and smelling salts, His nose is bleeding as well as his eye, and his chest is heaving. Gondorff comes out of his seat and up to the corner.
- Lonnegan is loving it.

seThelgtet) You can do it, Hooker. Kelley's gotta be tiring. A guy can only ish out so much punishment. The warning buzzer sounds. Hooker looks around to see Veronica.

joyfully anticipating Hooker's demise.

Hooker comes out, and much to Kelley's surprise, doesn't away. Hooker throws a right-left combination and actually lands one. Kelley counters with another swarm of blows, b Hooker stands his ground and comes ripping back. He smash a right to the chest, a left to the ribs and an overhand to the head. The fight is becoming a real slugfest. Kelle headhunting, throwing big haymakers, hooks and uppercuts. Hooker duc ing inside, jolting shots to the ribs and mid- section. Kelley's blows are more spectacularly visible fr even the cheap seats, but Hooker is dishing it out to the body and Kelley is beginning to feel it. Hooker gains mor and more confidence, if nothing else than for the fact he still on his feet, It's turning into a helluva fight, and the crowd is warming to it. All of them expect Lonnegan.
What the hell is goin' on here?

Hooker and Kelley are literally toe to toe now, trading punches as fast as their arms can work. One thing is be- coming increasingly clear, however. Kelley is beg nmning tire.” He has trained too little and thrown enough punche for three fights, and he's way behind on motivation. Hook senses it, and now his adrenalin really begins to flow. He's taken Kelley's best shots and Kelly knows it. Hooker rips a left to the stomach and follows with a righ to the side of the head. For the first time in the fight, Kelley begins to backpeddle, looking for a little breathi room.
One of the goons, Rossovich, returns, a big smile on his He's got the leather bag full of money with him.

The guy was still there. Grimes has got him out in the car. We got nothin’ to worry about. The bet's off. Rossavich doesn't get the show of gratitude out of Macali that he'd expected. At this point, Macalinski is not at a sure he wants that money back. cur TO  214 215 217 218

Hooker's really into it now, blasting away with both hand Hooker crowds Kelley and hammers away to the body. Kelley stabs out with his right, but the zip is gone from his punches. He tries to hold on, but Hooker pushes him away, and starts pounding again.
Lonnegan is speechless. Floyd looks like he's growing hemorrhoids.

Hooker backs Kelley into a corner, Kelley's punches are j awing the air now. This is the first round he's really thrown any punches, so unlike Kelley, h got something left despite the beating he's taken. Kelle rops his guard to protect his aching ribs and Hooker rock him with a right to the chin.

Eirie and The Big Ohio are going crazy in the corner. Bir is filling the air with imagina punches in an effort to u Hooker on. He throws one so hard he falls down. Gondorff, of course, has got to maintain his cool, having to preser the fiction that he's being double-crossed, but we know that he's exploding inside.

Hooker pummels away to the stomach again. Kelley's guard comes down and Hooker straightens him up with a wicked up cut that knocks Kelley's mouthpiece clean across the ring Kelley's arms are leaden. This time his guard stays down and his knees begin to sag. Hooker measures him, plants h feet and blasts a right to the nose, a right-left to the and cheekbone, and finally a prodigious uppercut that cat Kelley full on the chin. He wavers a second and pitches f ward on his face.

We pick up Hooker, Eirie, Gondorff, The Big Ohio and the Tuxedo Kid coming out another exit of the auditorium. The Big Ohio and the Tuxedo Kid climb into a car driven by Singleton. Gondorff, Hooker and Eirie pile into one drive by Billie. As the cars pull out, we: : cur To  227 228 229

{to Gondorff) So you knew all along what Lonnegan was doin', didn't ya?
Yeah, once I found out Lonnegan killed Twist and pinned it on Macalinski, I figured it from there. I had a little help with some of the details though.
From who?

Veronica. Both Hooker and Eirie are stunned. GONDORFF . I sent her up to Chicago to get next to Lonnegan the year I went into the pen. I knew he'd come after us as soon as I got out, so I figured I better have somebody watchin' him. Lonnegan hired her right away ‘cause he figured she'd be a great way to Keep an eye on us. He was the one that told her to get next to you. She tipped me off on everything she could, but she didn't find out about Twist until it was too late. This is all a little much for Hooker. He just slumps back in his seat in disbelief.

has recovered enough to speak.
Veronica. Jesus, why didn't ya tell me? All that hootchie-kootchie she was puttin’ out was part of the act. I mean she's givin' me these raven eyes and....

I never heard about no hootchie- kootchie and I don't want to. I woulda told ya she was in on the ground floor, but I didn't want ya to get too friendly with her. Babes and griftin' don't mix. I didn't know you were gonna go and get stuck on her anyway.
I'm not stuck on her. I just don't like playin' the patsy.
You oughta thank her for one thing. She helped Lonnegan get Snyder off your back. The car comes to a stop and Gondorff and the others get o We can't tell from the angle exactly where they are. cut TO

text: There's a noise at the door and all the agents spring int readiness. The door opens and one man walks in. The agent spring from their cover and surround him, gone leveled. O turns on the lights to reveal a little Delivery Boy with bouquet of flowers.
There a guy named Snyder here?
Before Snyder can answer, one of the agents reads the car on the bouquet.

Dear Snyder. Sorry we couldn't make it. Start the party without us. Love, Henry Gondorff. All the agents turn and focus their undying contempt on S a man who seems destined always to be in the right place wrong time. Right now, Snyder looks like he's gonna be il cur TO
Gondorff, Hooker, Eirie, Billie, Singleton, The Big Ohio the Tuxedo Kid are walking down the island to their train
Hey, wait a minute, I just thought of somethin'. If Macalinski took the money back from Tuxedo, we didn't make a dime on this thing.

Well we didn't exactly come away empty handed. The guy Veronica got Lonnegan to bet his money with was one of our guys too, Freddie Lake outa Jersey City. Hooker just shakes his head. He shoulda known it.
Then where's my split?
Veronica's got it.
What for?
I don't know. Why don't you ask her? She's in car ten, cabin six.
Hooker starts for car ten and then turns back to Gondorff
Henry? What made you think I could beat Kelley?

I don't know, Hooker, you got a way of ignoring the reality of things that always pulls you through. Some- day, you're gonna realize what you been doin' all these years and die of fright. I was wrong about one thing, though. I used to think you led a charmed life. Now I can see that you're just the gamest grifter I ever knew. Hooker smiles. He'll take that.
We follow him to car ten.
Hooker finds Veronica's compartment. The door is open.
Hooker's cheeks are slightly swollen and there's a bandag over his eye. He looks as bad as Veronica.
Gondorff tells me you got my split.
Yeah.
Then why aren't ya givin' it to me?
He told me you'd just blow it. I figured you could use it for better ngs. Like showin' me a good time.

(incensed) After all you done for me? You start out by takin' my money and then you make a sap outa me for the benefit of a guy who's been tryin’ to kill me for two years. 1% mean you coulda played your role for Lonnegan with- out all the lovey-dovey stuff, the

128 236 HOOKER (Cont'd) proper medical attention and all that. Jesus, you finally get me to the point where I can stand ya, and then I find out the whole thing has been a fake. Now you want me to take you places. I wouldn't be mich of a guy if I went for that.
I didn't say you'd be much. I said you'd be enough for me. Besides, the whole thing wasn't a fake.
Oh yeah, which parts?
What do ya think, ya jerk? I don't even know what I got to offer, but you got the best of it. Hooker looks at her a second, wondering if she really mea
_ I can't believe a thing you say any more, Sheridan. You haven't been straight with me one time since I met you. Veronica pulls out Hooker's money and throws it at him.
All right, here's your goddamn money. You don't deserve me anyway.
(picking it up and heading for the door) Sorry, lady, I don't mind you doin’ your job, but I don't like bein' played for a fool.
So long, Hooker. Thanks for the dance. Hooker nods and walks on out.
As Hooker gets to the end of the car, he comes face to fa with Gondorff counting a large amount of money into Kelle hands.

Hey, kid -- you had me worried you wouldn't make it through the first two rounds! (to Gondorff) Thanks, Mr. Gondorff. Kelley jumps off the train, stuffing the money into his p Hooker looks at Gondorff, who shrugs and grins sheepishly Hooker shakes his head helplessly and begins to laugh.

Hooker steps off the train as it starts to pull out, The go slowly past him as he heads back toward the terminal, hands deep down in his pockets, his mood turning serious. Just as the last car is about to go past him, he grabs th railing and swings himself back up on the train, a burgeo smile on his face. Helen Forrest's "Takin' A Chance On Lo comes up on the soundtrack and we hold on the train as it recedes into the distance. ‘I thought the cards were a frame up, I never would try. But now I'm taking the game up. And the ace of hearts is high. Things are mending now. I see a rainbow blending now. we'll have our happy ending now. Takin' A Chance On Love.'
